details.title: The recursive variance-reduction simulation algorithm for network reliability evaluation

authors.affiliation: Fac. de Ingenieria, Investigacion Operativa In.Co, Montevideo, Uruguay

p: Héctor Cancela received the Systems Engineer degree in 1990 from the Universidad de la Republica, Uruguay and the Ph.D. in Computer Science in 1996 from the University of Rennes 1, France. H. Cancela is currently Head of the Operations Research Department, within the Engineering Faculty at the Universidad de la Republica, Uruguay. He is also a researcher at the PEDECIBA (Uruguayan Program for the Development of Basic Sciences). His research work is centered on the performance evaluation and optimal design of computer, communication, and transport systems.

authors.name: H. Cancela

p: Mohamed El Khadiri received the Ph.D. in 1992 in Computer Science from the University of Rennes 1, France. Since 1993 he is Professor at the Logistics Management Department of Saint-Nazaire Institute of Technology. His research interests include sequential and parallel algorithms for telecommunication systems.

details.abstract: This paper proposes a new formulation of the recursive variance-reduction Monte Carlo estimator of the /spl kappa/ terminal unreliability parameter of communication systems. This formulation allows significant reduction in the simulation execution time, as demonstrated by experimental results.

references.title: Computational complexity of network reliability analysis: An overview

context.text:
Because exact evaluation of \$R({\cal{G}})\$ is \$N\!P\$-hard [1], Monte Carlo methods are used to obtain an estimate and a CI for the measure of interest [2]–
[6], [8], [9].

links.abstract: This paper presents an overview of results related to the computational complexity of network reliability analysis problems. Network reliability analysis problems deal with the determination of reliability measures for stochastic networks. We show how these problems are related to the more familiar computational network problems of recognizing certain subnetworks, finding optimal subnetworks, and counting certain subnetworks. We use these relationships to show that the k-terminal, the 2-terminal...

references.text: M. O. Ball, "Computational complexity of network reliability analysis: An overview", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-35, no. 3, pp. 230-239, Aug. 1986.

references.title: A recursive variance-reduction algorithm for estimating communication-network reliability

context.text:
Because exact evaluation of \$R({\cal{G}})\$ is \$N\!P\$-hard [1], Monte Carlo methods are used to obtain an estimate and a CI for the measure of interest [2]–
[6], [8], [9].
This paper proposes some improvements to the RVR estimator which is a sample mean based on the recursive r.v. \$F({\cal{G}})\$ defined in [2].

For a fixed sample size \$N\$, the algorithm in [2]for implementing the RVR method consists of a loop that calls \$N\$ times a recursive function \$F()\$ in order to obtain \$N\$ \$s\$-independent trials of \$F({\cal{G}})\$.
For a fixed sample size \$N\$, the RVR estimator is a sample mean based on \$N\$ \$s\$-independents trials \$F({\cal{G}})^{(1)},\,\ldots,\, F({\cal{G}})^{(N)}\$ of the r.v. \$F({\cal{G}})\$ [2].
Proposition 2.1 provides some of statistical characteristics of the r.v. \$F({\cal{G}})\$; the proof is in [2].
This section describes how the trial \$F({\cal{G}})^{(k)}\$ is generated in [2] when the reliability of \${\cal{G}}\$ is not the trivial \$(Q({\cal{G}}) = 1\$ or \$Q({\cal{G}})=0)\$.
A detailed algorithmic description of \$F(\cdot)\$ that returns a trial of \$F({\cal{G}})\$ is in [2].
the computational-times ratios and the variance ratios with respect to the crude Monte Carlo method (see [2] for an algorithmic description of the CMC method).

links.abstract: In evaluating the capacity of a communication network architecture to resist possible faults of some of its components, several reliability metrics are used. This paper considers the /spl Kscr/-terminal unreliability measure. The exact evaluation of this parameter is, in general, very costly since it is in the NP-hard family. An alternative to exact evaluation is to estimate it using Monte Carlo simulation. For highly reliable networks, the crude Monte Carlo technique is prohibitively expensive;...

references.text: H. Cancela, M. El Khadiri, "A recursive variance-reduction algorithm for estimating communication-network reliability", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 44, no. 4, pp. 595-602, Dec. 1995.

The same topology has been used in [3], [5], [6] to show the performances of several other Monte Carlo methods.

references.title: Series-parallel reductions in Monte Carlo network reliability evaluation

context.text:
Because exact evaluation of \$R({\cal{G}})\$ is \$N\!P\$-hard [1], Monte Carlo methods are used to obtain an estimate and a CI for the measure of interest [2]–[4]
[6], [8], [9].

In [4], the well-known series-parallel reductions (first developed in the setting of exact network-reliability evaluation [10], [11] were combined with the RVR technique, resulting in a more efficient RVR-SP.

links.abstract: Monte Carlo simulation appears to be very useful in the evaluation of K-terminal-reliability of large communication systems because the exact algorithms are extremely time consuming. This paper shows that the well-known series-parallel reductions can be incorporated in the recursive variance reduction simulation method, leading to a more efficient estimator, as demonstrated by experimental results.

references.text: H. Cancela, M. El Khadiri, "Series-parallel reductions in Monte Carlo network reliability evaluation", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 47, no. 2, pp. 159-164, Jun. 1998.

links.abstract: Monte Carlo techniques for estimating various network reliability characteristics, including terminal connectivity, are developed by assuming that edges are subject to failures with arbitrary probabilities and nodes are absolutely reliable. The core of the approach is introducing network time-evolution processes and using certain graph-theoretic machinery, resulting in a considerable increase in accuracy for Monte Carlo estimates, especially for highly reliable networks. Simulation strategies an...

references.text: T. Elperin, I. Gertsbakh, M. Lomonosov, "Estimation of network reliability using graph evolution models", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 40, no. 5, pp. 572-581, Dec. 1991.

links.abstract: This paper describes and compares the performance of four alternative Monte Carlo sampling plans for estimating the probability that two nodes, s and t, are connected in an undirected network whose arcs fail randomly and independently. Models of this type are commonly used when computing the reliability of a system of randomly failing components. The first method, dagger sampling, relies for its advantage on inducing negative correlation between the outcomes of the replications in the sample. Th...

references.text: G. S. Fishman, "A comparison of four Monte-Carlo methods for estimating the probability of s-t connectedness", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-35, no. 2, pp. 145-155, Jun. 1986.
